title: The Futurists - EPS_281: Super Inferno with Rob Tercek and Brett King

rawLines.text: this week on the futurists climate and
crisis the LA wildfires a random Cinder
might just blow down your Canyon and
ignite something and then suddenly
you're going to have a problem and you
never really know and so it's that
uncertainty that uncertainty and Dread
that hangs over everyone's head every
night that is actually the um the most
Telltale characteristic of living
through these fires
[Music]
welcome back to the futurists I'm your
host brick King and uh well you know
um we've obviously been talking a lot
about what's happening in LA with the
wildfires but we have at our disposal of
course Los
angelinos Los Angelino I guess we call
them a inhabitant of Los Angeles who's
been through the fires um I've I've got
a lot of friends who lost places at uh
on um you know the PCR and Malibu and in
the Palisades um you know this is it's
it's it's just the scale of this is
crazy but Rob um hi everybody you're
sort of our reporter on the ground in LA
but through this story uh as a resident
and uh I'm very happy to tell you a
little bit about it it's not a great
story but it's an interesting one
because it has a lot to tell us about
the future the future of big cities uh
so Brett great to see you again it's
been some time I'm very happy to connect
with you in the audience as well um so
the last several weeks here have been uh
the last two weeks he have been quite
intense in Los Angeles uh because of
wildfires Wildfire wildfires are nothing
new we get them every year you know um
people on the East Coast have four
seasons uh spring summer fall and winter
here we have spring and summer it gets
quite hot and then we have a dry season
which turns into a fire season almost
almost routinely around October or
November after the of the summer the
landscape is dried out but that's
usually followed by winter rain
sometimes they start in December
sometimes they start in January this
year is different so this year we have
not had rain here for 300 days so the
place is very dry uh we also had a very
hot summer and the previous two years we
had a lot of rain so there's been a
buildup of green things you know the
foilage and the hills has grown and
grown that's all fuel for fires so
everybody knew we were due for a big
fire season but I don't think anyone was
prepared preped for exactly what this is
and that is a couple reasons for that
but mainly you had all the all the
ingredients you could possibly imagine
to make for bad fire season a lot of
greenery in the Hills a long period
almost a year of no rain very hot summer
to dry everything out and then we got
the wind so normally our Santa Ana winds
come from the desert in October and
that's one of the things that drives the
fires they come out of the desert in to
the East and that means that they're
quite dry and they suck the moisture out
of the air they suck the moisture out of
your skin it's soy dry here Brett I was
typing to uh typing a note to a friend I
could feel the skin on my Knuckles when
I was typing I was like gosh that's an
unusual sensation like everything's
super dry if I walk in my backyard the
leaves are crunchy they're so dry they
turn to dust yeah and then um what
happened uh last Tuesday is we had wild
we had big winds and of course a
wildfire broke out now you may have
heard reports that the fire department
wasn't prepared that's not true they do
this all the time so they're quite well
uh prepared we have very good fire
department here um but they had put
their equipment where they expected the
sanana winds to come from and this is
what was different this is what was
unexpected the winds came from a
different direction and the Direction
They Came From First of all it wasn't
where they had the equipment position so
they had to move everything quickly but
the second thing is that the winds came
with such ferocity now Brett you can
probably see from the behind me uh that
my house is situated on a bluff I live
on a on a ridge a high ridge above a
wooded Canyon like many people in Los
Angeles it's one of the attributes that
makes a city such a beautiful city so
you can have uh you can live in the
hills and I'm right here in the far from
the Hollywood Sign yeah that's exactly
right you can walk to the Hollywood Sign
from here um and this is an old
neighborhood it's been around for 100
years for La that's quite old uh so you
know this place has survived but there
were fires here in the past it's it's a
very fire prone area we're in the fire
zone and many many other people
thousands of people have houses on the
Hills because it's so beautiful but
these Hills have some attributes that
are really dangerous in a fire uh the
first one of course is that the streets
are quite narrow and twisty so it makes
it hard for people to drive up and down
they're also so narrow that you can't
actually drive two cars at once uh you
have to be careful as you pass upcoming
Vehicles so during a fire this is fire
engines yeah you can't bring the Fire
Equipment in so that's problem number
one and then the second problem is that
um because we're up high there's a
certain Dynamic that the fire has it
comes roaring down the canyon canyons
are like narrow narrow and they'll go
for miles right so most of these canyons
are four miles or three miles long right
because it's a Wind Tunnel right it
builds into a wind tunnel and the heat
kind of creates its own weather system
which can intensify the winds so the
winds in the canyon can be up to 100
miles an hour and that's what we had
last Tuesday so imagine winds that were
blowing so hard Brett last week I have a
lot of trees in my yard they were
sideways the wind was pushing mature
trees sideways I had two trees from my
neighbor fall into my yard they took out
some of my trees as they fell I had a
tree in my yard that was blown so hard
it cut another Tree in half it
decapitated another tree and these are
mature trees so imagine this intense
wind blowing it's constant it's
constantly windy but it comes in gust so
strong wind warm
dry pushing fire now those palm trees uh
they are so famous they're kind of
iconic palm trees that we've got well
when those start to burn at the top they
shoot Sparks and they shoot Sparks
really really fast they the as they
disintegrate they turn into Cinders but
with the wind like that it turns a palm
tree that's burning into a kind of
machine gun that shoots out Sparks
hundreds of of Sparks per minute are
getting shot at a velocity could be it
could be 100 miles hour with the wind
the those burning Cinders can go for
hundreds they can go for hundreds of
feet they can go for a mile sometimes so
you have a situation then where the wind
is moving much faster than a motor
vehicle it's moving down these Canyons
that intensify it and it's moving so
fast that the fire department can't even
reposition their equipment in time to
get to the next fire and so it's almost
like a wall of flame that marches across
the Foothills in front of the uh in
front of the mountains now we do have
these big big mountains on the edge town
the St Gabriel's uh those are burning
right now that's where one of the worst
fires is uh that rugged landscape is so
steep you can't climb it so there's no
way to fight the fire they would
typically let it just burn but the
Foothills in front are some of the most
valuable real estate in Los Angeles many
many people live there beautiful homes
they've been there for hundred years
these are really wellestablished
neighborhoods family
neighborhoods those towns have burned to
the ground yeah there is nothing left of

parts of pales Pacific Palisades was the
nicest neighborhood in Los Angeles the
homes there were 5 to7 million a
beautiful place where movie stars and

their homes that neighborhood is burned
to the ground it's unrecognizable and
when you see the footage and I'm sure

nothing left no home is left no school
uh the shopping malls the grocery stores

where there's just a couple gter
standing it's so hot that they're

they're finding that the metal structure
is melted completely into a puddle so
that's how hot it is we're talking like
hundreds of degrees of
heat um I'm bringing all that up because

from people don't live here is gosh the

didn't respond well well they they
didn't take water from the ocean because

right so the aircraft are really

they can't fly in high wind uh but but

there was no human Agency on earth that
could stop 100 mph wind that's moving

propose to do then some people say well

they poured millions of gallons of water

brother it's a 40 foot wall of flame
because of because of how big it is
right huge firefront um so it it of
course now it is the most
costly economic loss for a natural

um
losses but that number keeps going up so

so which is about 900 billion so you

that's exactly the point that's why I

they're not going to underwrite a house
